title: Tuesday, 2nd May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM11:02am

Morning

PM11:03am

Sorry, a tad late this morning

PM11:03am

I hadn't noticed the time.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

So let me get a pic up

PM11:03am

I thought -- someone we haven't had on here for some time

PM11:03am

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Yanis

PM11:03am

Not because of the greek re-bailout technical stuff

PM11:04am

But because of the kerfuffle over this dinner

11:04 am
PM11:04am

May and Juncker

PM11:04am

As has been pointed out, May is coming up against the playbook deployed against Greece.

PM11:05am

So who better to offer her advice than Yanis

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Ambrose EP has taken this angle

PM11:05am

Here http://www.telegra...avoid-negotiating/

PM11:06am

And in the words of Yanis...

11:05 am
PM11:06am

My advice to Theresa May is to avoid negotiation at all costs. If she doesn’t do that she will fall into the trap of Alexis Tsipras, and it will end in capitulation... The parallel with Brexit is the tactic of stalling negotiations. They will get you on the sequencing. First there is the price of divorce to sort out before they will talk about free trade in the future...They will give you the EU run-around. You won’t always know exactly who to talk to and that is deliberate.

PM11:06am

Not sure how that works -- just not negotiating

PM11:06am

But whatever

11:06 am
undefined
PM11:07am

SO Bryce -- what's going on. Sterling up and stocks up.

PM11:07am

So this is a breakdown of some sort

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Um .......... I guess, very occasionally, we have to view the market as something other than a secondary effect of cable.

BE11:08am

Not often, I admit, but occasionally.

PM11:08am

hmm

11:08 am
BE11:09am

And, yep, we're up 32 points at 7,236. Follow on from Wall Street and suchlike.

PM11:09am

We're being forced to go straight for Ocado

PM11:09am

Kinda irresistable

11:09 am
PM11:09am

M&S tie up hopes/fantasy/speculation

BE11:09am

Hm, so Sunday Telegraph with the scoop of interpretation.

PM11:10am

It's like an 'idea' presented as news

11:10 am
BE11:10am

This is M&S confirming that it'd quite like an online grocery business ........

BE11:11am

.......... so, who does online grocery outsourcing? Ocado does! Are they talking yet? No. Will they probably talk some time in the very near future? Probably!

PM11:11am

They are 'eyeing' talks

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Great piece of journalese -- 'eyeing'

BE11:12am

I mean, it's a great Sunday story in the sense that it squeezed out the available information and beats it up into a splash. That's good Sundaying.

BE11:13am

(We've both worked at Sundays, briefly. It's a terrible life. Please note this is written from the perspective of sympathy rather than criticism.)

11:12 am
PM11:13am

Yeah -- here's the actual piece http://www.telegra...delivery-shake-up/

BE11:13am

So, should we put some numbers on this idea?

PM11:13am

Go on then

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Here's Credit Suisse to kick it around.

PM11:13am

Just in case they become relevant

PM11:13am

The numbers that is. Not CS

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We see M&S products on ocado.com as the best solution. A supply agreement similar to the Morrisons / Amazon deal is the best case scenario for both companies. M&S's range is too narrow and its basket size too small to offer a credible standalone online grocery service - a 'white label' deal (like Morrisons) does not make sense to us. However, listing M&S products on Ocado's website does. Ocado has: (i) high-quality distribution that would have an immediate impact on volumes; (ii) similar brand positioning; and (iii) a broad enough range to bring basket sizes up to an economic level. On the other hand, we would be disappointed if M&S were to use Ocado's store-pick technology to bypass centralised distribution due to its limited value to Ocado and the inherent losses of a store-pick model.

BE11:13am

Amazon less likely, but not out of the question. Having discontinued GM distribution with Amazon, we find it unlikely that M&S would re-engage with food - disregarding considerations as whether it would be a brand-enhancing exercise.

BE11:14am

However, for Amazon, the potential to access a loyal and lucrative segment of the market may provide enough of a draw to offer lucrative terms to M&S. At the very least, M&S would be able to create pricing tension between Amazon and Ocado to drive the best deal.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Waitrose agreement is a potential stumbling block. Waitrose receives a fee on 100% of Ocado's total sales (not just on products supplied by them). They also receive the volume and growth benefits of Ocado's sales, which bolsters its own buyers' influence. The current contract limits Ocado to a minimum of 70% Waitrose-branded private label sales, giving Waitrose a guaranteed channel and limiting Ocado's flexibility to offer substitutions. It is unclear whether M&S product would be considered 'branded', thereby preventing their listing, but the ability to renegotiate the contract is always available. We think Waitrose could be persuaded to agree to M&S coming on to Ocado's platform.

BE11:14am

Positive for sentiment regardless of pricing scenario. Assuming an supply agreement approach, we would expect Ocado to see volume growth after filling the only mass-market product gap in its offering. For M&S, it might be better for sentiment than its financials as we would assume 25-50% of online sales would be cannibalised from stores, and the split with Ocado would reduce margins below 33% retail gross margin.

BE11:14am

Which is a lot of analysis on a possibility.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Here's Bernstein as well. Or perhaps just a bit of Bernstein.

BE11:15am

Two options for M&S if they go with an Ocado solution: the CFC central fulfilment solution or in-store picking. Typically M&S has customers shop smaller baskets, serving customers in the 'something-for-tonight' or 'top-up' shopping missions rather than the 'main shop'. The economics of central fulfilment are hugely in favour of bigger baskets (taking the basket size down from £100 to £75 to and EBIT swings from +1% margin to -8%). Hence, it's more likely that a solution would be in store pick for M&S.

BE11:15am

In-store pick solution won't have as much impact on Ocado share price. For a long time Ocado had rejected the in-store pick model and it isn't where their investments and expertise lie. There are also plenty of competitors for Ocado in this format (start-ups such as Instacart, Toggle) as well as the retailers themselves.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Profitability of a deal for Ocado could be £2-4m medium term. Ocado has made ~£12m from Morrisons each of the last 3 years. M&S food sales are ~half of the size of MRW and they're unlikely to be asked to pay the hefty (£8m) R&D fee as MRW were. Profit to Ocado could be in the region of £2-4m in the medium term. This could be significantly lower if there was a competitive bid process with other players vying to provide an in-store pick solution for M&S.

PM11:16am

Waitrose receives a fee on 100% of Ocado's total sales -- not just on products supplied by them? I didn't know this.

PM11:16am

That would be hilarious -- Waitrose getting paid for M&S to sell warm up dinners

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Hm. A reminder that, in Ocado, you're paying 30x EV/EBITDA for a grocer with a ~1% market share and a structural price disadvantage to its competitors.

BE11:17am

You're paying that because of the possibility of an international licencing deal.

BE11:17am

M&S -- should it happen -- isn't international, nor is it a licencing deal.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

It'd be incremental sales to add to the system, and Ocado will have to pitch its offer cheaper than Amazon to win those incremental sales.

BE11:18am

I reiterate, cheaper than Amazon ......

BE11:18am

Up 6.5% tho. So clearly, the market's seeing something I don't.

11:19 am
undefined
PM11:19am

Shall we stick with stocks we have a beef with?

PM11:19am

Just Eat, for example?

11:19 am
BE11:20am

I see. We're theming the entire show for agoraphobics.

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 556.50, down 20.5 (-3.55%), High: 567.50, Low: 544.00, Volume: 2.98m
BE11:20am

Q1's fine, sort of. 46% sales growth.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

25% order growth LFL.

PM11:21am

Which is extraorinday, to be fair

PM11:21am

Albeit not as extraordinary as some people wanted

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Indeed. International growing faster than UK, which is down to 17%, so we can have a punt at the whole "mature market slowing down or competitive forces?" thing.

BE11:22am

FY guidance unchanged.

BE11:22am

Which isn't good enough when you're paying an Ocado-like multiple here.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Here's UBS's summary of, and mostly repeating, what I just typed.

BE11:23am

Just Eat reported strong Q1 revenue growth at +46% yoy (+40% LFL) vs. our expectations of +38% for H1. Q1 order growth of +25% yoy on a like-for-like basis at the group level was slightly below our expectations for H1 of +27%. UK orders grew +17% in Q1, in line with the company's stated guidance of mid to high teens growth, but 3p.p. below our expectations of +20% for H1. Excluding the additional leap year trading day and Easter falling in Q1 in 2016, order growth would have been +19%, according to the company. The company reiterated its FY guidance in terms of revenues and EBITDA. We believe this quarter shows JE's ability to further monetize its platform, but believe that market concerns over UK competition will linger.

BE11:24am

And Jefferies ........

11:24 am
BE11:24am

JE, as ever, generates much debate. The stock flat YTD at 577p, FTSE 250 +8%, the FY17 guide, broadly in-line with consensus, implied UK order growth, 'mid to late teens', the impending UK Government review of the 'gig economy' and succession planning also, arguably continues to be a thorny issue.

BE11:24am

2017 consensus for context. The JE disclosed numbers here, 2017 revenue £488m, adjusted EBITDA £157m. One moving piece, the inclusion of the Canadian STD acquisition, we assume a contribution c.£25m revenue and a c.(£5m) adjusted EBITDA loss, at the mid-point of the guide, the LfL numbers are revenue £462.5m, +23% YoY growth and adjusted EBITDA £163.5m, a 35.4% margin.

Today's 1Q17 update. Perhaps five key points;

Group revenue £118.9m, +45.9% YoY on a reported basis, more akin to +40% on a LfL basis, though that appears to include STD;
Group orders 39.0m, +23.8%, and c. +25% on a LfL basis. The main delta here between revenue and orders, the timing of the 2016 commission rate increases;
Within the UK, one suspects still key to sentiment, 24.0m orders, +16.5% YoY. Could highlight the timing of Easter and the Leap Year impact, that number kind of LfL, more +19%. JEFe +18% FY17 for our modestly ahead consensus FY17 forecasts;
International orders, 15.0m, +37.6% YoY, +43% LfL; and
Unsurprisingly given that the FY17 guide was set only on 7 March, the guide maintained.

In conclusion. A tough quarter for JE, hard comps and some operational issues evident. Given that, a solid outcome, investor sentiment may home in on the UK and +16.5% order growth, consistent with the FY17 guide.

BE11:25am

We can also note, without dwelling on, Chairman John Hughes being signed off work for health reasons last week.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Jefferies again .....

BE11:25am

Succession...always a tough one to analyse. On one hand, we recognise the incredibly strong bench at JE, Harrison, Fanton, Dawe, Hillier, Gavin, Blair and Corfield to name but a few. And of course we wish Chairman John Hughes, the fullest and speediest recovery. Yet, we do contemplate from time to time, the wisdom of changing both CEO and CFO within twelve months.

PM11:26am

hmm

11:26 am
BE11:26am

And some more valuation work, since there's not much in today's update that changes the story really.

BE11:26am

JUST EAT remains the cheapest stock in our UK Internet coverage on a PEG basis, offering sector-leading earnings growth but trading on a cal.2018E EV/EBITDA of 16.9x, a discount to premium play Rightmove, and 26.4x PER.

BE11:26am

That's Canaccord.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Is PEG the right valuation for Just Eat? I mean, its growth isn't like a normal internet company, where there's a near infinite amount of road in which to expand sales.

BE11:27am

It does takeaways.

PM11:28am

Specifically, takeaways from chicken shops

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Yes. And unless its customers start ordering multiple takeaways from chicken shops each evening, there must be a natural ceiling to demand.

BE11:28am

Which brings us back to the UK slowing thing.

BE11:29am

Numis says 34.2x 2017 PE, reducing to 15x 2020.

11:29 am
undefined
PM11:30am

So all the miners a bit weak

PM11:30am

Is this on the back of China slowing?

11:30 am
PM11:30am

China PMIs earlier

PM11:30am

Let me get some Cap Economics

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:30 am
PM11:31am

There are a couple of key takeaways from the breakdown of the surveys. First, the export orders sub-indices of both PMIs held up relatively well despite larger drops in overall new orders, suggesting that cooling domestic demand is primarily what is weighing on activity. This fits with our view that underlying investment demand has weakened recently despite faster nominal growth in capital spending. (See our Update, “Investment not as strong as meets the eye“, 18th April.) Second, the price indices of both PMIs fell sharply, consistent with our projection for producer price inflation to drop back markedly in the coming months.

Finally, momentum in the rest of the economy also appears to have softened last month. The official non-manufacturing PMI dropped from 55.1 to a six-month low of 54.0.

The latest PMI readings aren’t the first sign that China’s economy has started to soften as the tailwinds from policy easing fade. Our China Activity Proxy (CAP) has been pointing to slower growth in recent months, after peaking in December. (See our latest China Activity Monitor for details.) But the PMI readings for April appear to confirm this downward trend and suggest that the slowdown has extended into Q2.

PM11:31am

Copper price up tho, weirdly

PM11:32am

But...

11:32 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 296.70, down 6.95 (-2.29%), High: 307.10, Low: 296.25, Volume: 16.24m
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,160, down 15.1 (-1.29%), High: 1,188, Low: 1,159, Volume: 2.75m
PM11:32am

Etc

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Not particularly. Liberum's quant thingy's turned red on the data you just quoted.

BE11:33am

[O]ur Restocking Indicator move to a sector SELL recommendation for the first time since November 2015 with a reading of 0.83 (below 0.9 signals SELL). This is a significant step down from April and adds short-term conviction to our underweight call, which we expect will gain momentum into the second half in the absence of a material policy reversal in China.

BE11:33am

Here's what that looks like in chart form.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Or will be when ShareX works.

BE11:34am

BE11:34am

The main driver of the Restocking Indicator is the inventory ratio, which looks at expectations of raw material inventories at mills (iron ore, coking coal) over expectations of finished product (steel) inventories. A higher ratio implies mills expect finished product to be drawn down at faster rate than raw materials are replenished, signalling a tight market, whilst a low reading signals the opposite.

The inventory ratio came in at 0.83, expectations of finished steel inventories at 55.5 (highest reading since December 2014) and expectations of raw material inventories at 45.9 (lowest reading since January 2016). In combination, the inventory ratio hasn't reached this level since November 2015, where it hit 0.68 and the sector fell 8.4%.

A good illustration of how the drawdown in steel inventories has under-performed expectations can be seen in the YoY of Chinese steel inventories held at traders, which inflected last month, implying a slower demand than this time last year.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

BE11:35am

And that's that, I guess.

undefined
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Sellside wise, there's N Brown

N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 255.25, up 16.75 (+7.02%), High: 257.50, Low: 244.25, Volume: 659.98k
PM11:36am

Quite a move

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Who is pushing this?

BE11:36am

HSBC.

BE11:37am

Note is quite "turnaround" .......

11:37 am
BE11:37am

As in, online is growing at a decent rate

BE11:38am

......... product rejig improves margins, etc.

BE11:38am

Oddly little about the fact that N Brown is a sub-prime lender that has a sideline selling dresses.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Which I thought was the market's main concern really, given the focus of the FCA on credit-reliant businesses that have a tendency to roll over their customers to rather higher rates than the ones initially offered.

BE11:39am

Anyway, here's HSBC.

BE11:39am

1. More flexible sourcing with increased open-to-buy ratios (now 45% at JD Williams and 65% at Simply BE) and reduced lead times (down 20% y-o-y)

11:40 am
BE11:40am

2. New product collections at JD Williams (‘The Cut’) and Simply Be (‘Unique’). The result is a broad based improvement in customer, product, online and Financial Services (FS) KPI’s that contributed to a 10% increase in online sales with Power Brands +14%. Underlying Power Brand sales were +9% driven by an improved performance in womenswear (JD Williams +12%, Simply Be +10%) which accelerated in the H2. This is before the dilutive impact of the migration of the Fifty Plus title into JD Williams which will complete by the half year. The group delivered share gains in 16+ size (80bps), 20+ size (280bps) and greater than 65 (+50bps) womenswear markets. While FS sales growth was broadly flat there was good progress on arrears and reduced provisions via the sale of high risk payment arrangement debt.

BE11:40am

Risk profile improving on increased exposure to online: Online now represents 69% of total sales and 77% of new customer sales with strong growth in mobile. Increased exposure to online channels improves N Brown’s ability to mitigate a challenging FY17-18 consumer outlook. From a transformation plan perspective the ‘Fit 4 the Future’ IT project is critical to realising group potential. Progress is in in line with expectation. N Brown landed its first new international (US) platform in 2016 and will land its first new UK platform (High & Mighty) in 2017. The group has also landed new finance, merchandising, and parts of the new credit system. Delaying the roll out of new online sites to Power Brands until 2018, the point at which the majority of the new online customer functionality has landed, reduces execution risk and maxmises potential returns.

BE11:40am

Buy (from Hold) on a new TP of 280p (from 215p): The FY17 results were in line with expectation. FY18e guidance suggests a broadly unchanged earnings outlook. FX is the big swing factor but where the group has hedged 90% of USD exposure at $/£1.27.
However it is not earnings but a reduced risk profile that drives in the increase in in our TP to 280p (from 215p) as we switch back to the company specific beta (1.0 from 1.2) applied to our APV valuation. N Brown currently trades on a CY17e PE of 11.1 declining to 10.8 in CY18e underpinned by a 5.9% dividend yield compared to a sector ave at 13.0 and 12.3 respectively. Our revised TP implies 16.7% upside and a PE multiple in line with the sector average.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

KPI table provides an interesting summary of what N Brown is all about. Shows 9,.9% of customers in arrears, which is down a percentage point from 2016.

BE11:43am

And new credit recruits of 129k, again a bit down on 2016. But Kadhim's already done some stuff on N Brown's credit business that's well worth reading, so I'll just direct you to that and leave it there.

BE11:43am

https://ftalphavil...-credit-addiction/

11:46 am

PM11:47am

The magic wood stuff, btw, is umbila

PM11:47am

https://en.wikiped...ocarpus_angolensis

11:47 am
PM11:47am

It is valued for several medicinal uses. It has been recorded to treat ringworm, eye problems, blackwater fever, stabbing pains, malaria, and to increase the supply of breast milk. The resemblance of the sap to blood has led to the belief in supposed magical healing powers concerning the blood. Because of all these reasons and that it is also fire resistant, P. angolensis is sometimes planted around the chief's enclosure to make a living fence.

PM11:48am

There's been a big clampdown on illegal logging in Moz -- and there's currently an extension to the annual 3 month ban on logging.

PM11:48am

So Obtala are building a bit new sawmill in the north of the country.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Anywhere -- just one to keep an eye on.

undefined
BE11:48am

(@Fatdaz: A1 reference.)

11:49 am
BE11:49am

So, from a stock that trades at 0.3252p, we should probably head up the market a bit.

BE11:49am

There was a mention of BP earlier.

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 449.10, up 6.6 (+1.49%), High: 455.65, Low: 448.10, Volume: 9.80m
11:49 am
PM11:50am

Oh yeah -- Q1s

PM11:50am

http://www.investe...1705020700167975D/

BE11:50am

They're mixed, though in unsurprising ways.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Macondo's still eating all the cash, with the effect that the divi's uncovered.

PM11:51am

(chad_john -- i never see Winnifrith's stuff. His emails are on an auto-gmail-delete)

PM11:51am

BP divi uncovered??

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Yep. Has been for some time. The good news -- if you want to see to what way -- is that without Macondo the divi would be covered.

BE11:52am

Which it hasn't been, even underlying, since mid 2014.

BE11:52am

The big cost shift for $50 oil took quite a while, and arguably hasn't fully happened even now.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Have Morgan Stanley to do the numbers. There's a lot of them, as usual.

BE11:53am

E&P (higher/ lower/ in-line vs. consensus): Underlying replacement cost profit of $1,370m was ahead of consensus of $1,150m. Production of 2,388 kboe/d came in modestly stronger than our forecast of 2,371 kboe/d. Quarter-on-quarter, production increased 9%, of which 6% was due to the ADCO acquisition whilst the remaining 3% reflects underlying growth.

BE11:53am

R&M (higher/ lower/ in-line vs. consensus): BP delivered adjusted R&M EBIT of $1,742m vs. consensus of $1,410m. BP's Whiting refinery returned from maintenance, and the contribution from trading also bounced back in 1Q.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Tax: BP's adjusted effective tax rate was 33% in 1Q17. This increased sharply from 18% last year, mostly due to the ADCO acquisition. However, the tax rate was still lower than the guided 40%.

BE11:54am

FCF improved; 109% dividend cover ex-Macondo: BP made $2.3bn of cash payments 1Q related to the Macondo incident, which should be close to half of this year's total payment of $4.5-5.5bn. Excluding this amount, BP generated operating cash flow (excl. working capital changes) of $5.7bn in 1Q. Organic capex was $3.5bn, leaving organic FCF of $2.2bn. That exceeds BP's quarterly dividend of $2.0bn for the first time since 3Q14.

Gearing in-line: net debt of $38.6bn was in-line with our forecast of $38.4bn.

Capex guidance unchanged: BP expects 2017 capex to be $15-17bn, in-line with previous statements.

BE11:54am

The argument from here is summed up in this DB note from last month: https://www.ft.com...-a53d-df09f373be87

11:55 am
BE11:55am

As in, Macondo costs are front loaded and production's now coming online quickly, so divi cover should improve rapidly as we head towards the end of the decade.

BE11:56am

Though that $38.6bn of net debt might be a factor to note in that argument.

BE11:56am

Here's Brendan Warn at BMO.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Improving ability to generate OCF. The 28% gearing is ~200bps higher than YE2016 and close to the 30% financial framework ceiling; however, we believe this has peaked for the year. Q1 was anomalous as it was driven by a larger Macondo payment, Working Capital build, and minimal disposals receipts. We don't anticipate significant progress during the second quarter; however, we believe that gearing could reduce to

$1.0 billion, with $17 billion remaining the hard ceiling. In 2017, we forecast organic capex of ~$16 billion, with upstream $13.5 billion, of which ~60% for major projects and <10% exploration.

De-risked project start-up portfolio - four out of the seven on-line by mid-2017. BP has announced the start of the Trinidad Onshore Compression project and West Nile Delta - Taurus/Libra and continues to forecast, a further two projects: Quad 204 and Juniper, on stream by mid-2017. 2H17 will see Khazzan, Persephone and Zohr also achieve a start.
High impact Senegal - Mauritania exploration has commenced. The first exploration results expected within 2-3 weeks, with Yakaar (15TCF/ 750-1500mmbbl gross unrisked, BP: ~60% W.I.) currently being tested. The initial four-well programme is testing greater than 10-15 bn boe of gas-liquids potential. Well results are anticipated every 50-70 days.
We continue to see BP trading at levels in-line with the global majors (ex-XOM) at ~19.9x P/E, 6.7x EV/DACF (2018E) based on $55/bbl oil price.

The latest PMI readings support our view that growth in China peaked at the turn of the year and is now decelerating.

The Caixin manufacturing PMI declined from 51.2 in March to a seven-month low of 50.3 last month. This was weaker than the forecasts of all economists polled by Bloomberg (the median was 51.3 and our own forecast was 51.0). The official manufacturing PMI (published on Sunday) also undershot expectations, falling from 51.8 to 51.2 (Bloomberg 51.7; CE 51.5).
